contentlets.description: The course examines the evolutionary history of life on earth from origins to humans and the relationship between environment, adaptation and function. Animal (particularly human) and plant physiology are covered with an emphasis placed on adaptation in the Australian context.
contentlets.title: Evolutionary and Functional Biology

The course develops student skills in critically assessing scientific information, routinely debated by the public and decision-makers. It provides a strong grounding in today's and tomorrow's environmental problems and the role of science in providing solutions.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"667521f3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self- Guided Practicals and Short Answer Response Questions","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Rationale:

 

  • To expose students to active conservation programs.
  • To highlight the important role that Zoos play in educating the public on matters of conservation and sustainability.

 

Description:

 

  • Part A- students complete one self-guided practical (to Taronga Zoo).
  • Part B- students complete short answer questions on the importance and effectiveness of Zoos in educating the public on matters of conservation and sustainability. Feedback is provided online as written feedback.
  • Total 15%
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e67521f3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5a7521f3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961990","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes and Biodiversity Measurement Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Rationale:

  • to guide students through all components of the scientific process- from data collection, analysis, research and report writing
  • to teach students how to identify, find and use scientific literature
  • to ensure students understand the structure of a scientific report

 

Description:

  • Part A, Complete 2 online quizzes 5% (quiz 1.- the importance of scientific literature and quiz 2. -the structure of a scientific report). Feedback is immediate after the completion of the quiz (right or wrong answers).
  • Part B, Biodiversity Measurement Report 15%. Students analyse data collected during field trips to Centennial Park and Randwick Environment Park. Students are then required to write up their findings in the form of a scientific report. Students can reflect on the skills learnt during the quizzes to help them find appropriate scientific literature and write and structure the report. Feedback is provided during and after the assessment (written and verbally during class).
  • Total 20%

Rationale:

 

  • to test the students understanding of the theory content, covered during the lectures and revision sessions.

 

Description:

 

  • Written exam (40 multiple choice questions and 20 short answer response questions). Feedback through final grade only.
  • Total 50%

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e67521f3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"927521f3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Threats to Global Biodiversity Video","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Rationale:

 

  • To develop science communication, problem solving and team work skills.

 

Description:

 

    • Each group is required to produce a 4-minute video on a threatened ecosystem. The video must describe the ecosystem, outline why it is important, identify key threats to the ecosystem and provide a creative solution to save the ecosystem for future generations. 15% ( 5% peer reviewed mark). Feedback is provided during and after the assessment (written and verbally during class).
    • Total 15%

contentlets.description: This course provides an introduction to ecology, sustainability and environmental science, introducing a range of biological topics and how scientists approach these topics to solve problems. The course develops student skills in critically assessing scientific information, routinely debated by the public and decision-makers.  It provides a strong grounding in today's and tomorrow's environmental problems and the role of science in providing solutions.
contentlets.title: Ecology, Sustainability and Environmental Science

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS1501 - Australia's Unique and Deadly Animals and Plants","description":"

The Australian fauna and flora evolved during a long period of isolation from the biota of other continents. For that reason, many of the animals and plants of Australia are unique because evolution has taken an alternative direction. A world renowned and distinctive aspect of Australia is the large number of dangerous animals, particularly, venomous animals. Even many plants in Australia are venomous and have a deadly sting.  The Australian environment provides many deadly challenges to its visitors. However, aside from simply having a reputation as being a dangerous place the characteristics which make the Australian flora and fauna so distinctive and the reasons why it is so distinctive are poorly understood by most people.


In this course students will learn about how evolutionary isolation has made the Australian fauna and flora so distinct. Along the way students will learn about the deadly animals and plants of Australia and how to identify them. Students will also learn about why this long period of isolation has made the Australian fauna so vulnerable to the threats posed by introduced species. This course will involve some day trip excursions and will incur a small cost to students (approximately $100).

The final exam will cover the entire course content and concepts with emphasis on the material presented after the early term test.  The exam will be multiple choice. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"27f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"abf599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e7f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ff599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Early term test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This test will assess students understanding of the concepts covered in the lectures and practicals in the first three weeks of the term.  The test will be multiple choice and/or short answer questions, and marks will be returned to students within one week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"53f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Deadly seas assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will complete an assignment based on ocean dangers and deadly ocean creatures explored in the one-day field trip to the beach, and in the associated lecture on ocean dangers.  Questions will explore the life history and evolutionary origins of these marine animals.  Students will receive written feedback within 10 days of the assignment submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"27f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e7f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9bf599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Deadly land assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will complete an assignment on Australia’s deadly terrestrial fauna explored in the one-day field trip to the Australian Reptile Park and associated lectures on deadly terrestrial animals.  Questions will explore the life history and unique evolutionary history of Australia’s terrestrial fauna.  Students will receive written feedback within 10 days of the assignment submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BIOS2011","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS2011 - Evolutionary and Physiological Ecology","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the functional relationships between living organisms and the environments in which they live. There is an emphasis on interactions within and between populations, ecological energetics, ecophysiology, and the theory of evolution by natural selection. In this, we cover a wide range of life forms from plants, animals, and microbes. This course also serves as an introduction to the process of scientific enquiry.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a923e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a96192e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Lecture Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"36","description":"

Lecture Quizzes

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a923e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3923e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Projects","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Three laboratory studies will be conducted throughout the session.  Students will submit data, details of analysis, and interpretation of their results at the end of each of these studies.  Feedback will be provided by academics and demonstrators.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Biological Start-up","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"9","description":"

Students will explore scientific entrepeneurship through developing a scientific start-up linking concepts in ecology and evolution to government and industry. Students will develop ideas (a "lean canvas"), write a grant application and develop an industry pitch for funding and collaboration.  Feedback will be given by demonstrators and academics after each stage of the project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a523e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a923e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Science Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will collaborate with team members to communicate the relevance of ecology and evolution to contemporary issues in society. The project will include a proposal, project updates, and the creation of a podcast. Feedback at each stage will be given by demonstrators, peers and course academics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a923e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ad23e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f123e532db8ea810eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS2011.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BIOS2031","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS2031 - Biology of Invertebrates","description":"

A study of invertebrate diversity emphasising their evolution, morphology, behaviour, and relationships to marine, freshwater and terrestrial environments. Invertebrate conservation and applied aspects of invertebrate biology are included. Practical work includes examining living and preserved specimens (including dissections) in the laboratory and the field, and techniques for invertebrate identification. Assumed knowledge: BIOS1101.Note/s: Enrolment in this course may be subject to quota restrictions. Such restrictions will only apply to students taking this course as an elective. There is a compulsory field camp during the term and personal expenses will be incurred.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b3e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field survey report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

You are required to submit a report outlining the results from invertebrate field survey conducted at Chowder Bay, Sydney Harbour National Park. The report will address questions about:

  1. The diversity of invertebrates collected from the survey, and,
  2. The structure, feeding and reproduction of invertebrates in the habitats surveyed.

Feedback and marks from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7be36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2fe36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The practical classes will expose you to a great range of live and preserved invertebrates. Classes are divided into several components, each relating to an aspect of invertebrate biology, including diversity, structure, feeding, reproduction and development, behavioural observation/experiment, and invertebrate research at UNSW. Within each component there are several tasks. These may involve; 1) written questions, 2) providing a labelled diagram of an organism or structure, 3) providing the results of a short experiment, or 4) providing illustrated notes on a particular aspect of feeding, reproduction or behaviour.

Your understanding of these tasks will be assessed in the practical exam, along with new displays to test student ability to identify invertebrates, knowledge of the distinguishing characters of the major taxonomic groups, and knowledge of the structure and function of invertebrates covered in the practical classes.

Marks will be provided one week after the exam

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7be36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a96199e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam tests comprehension of all material covered in lectures and practical classes

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7be36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b7e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"afe36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Popular Science Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

In this article, you are required to independently research the ways in which the lives of invertebrates and humans interact, and write an article suitable for a popular science audience. You should demonstrate scientific knowledge of the invertebrate groups researched, but also be able to argue to a wide audience how this knowledge is valuable.

This project aims to:

  • emphasise the links between the biology of invertebrates and human activities
  • provide experience in independent research
  • provide experience in the communication of scientific information to a broad audience

Feedback and marks from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7be36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b7e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e3e36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS2031.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Practical work includes light microscopy; plant anatomy and identification.Assumed knowledge: BIOS1101.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"449b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961942","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final (theory) Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam is a test of the conceptual material included in the lectures including an understanding of the ecology and evolution of plants.  This assessment will be more integrative rather than about memorization and will test the ability to put concepts together and build an integrative understanding of plants.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"489b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f8b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"889b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"278be9b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tests of practical skills","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

These test the key practical skills for the course: plant ID, key family identification, using keys properly, anatomical identification (ie. identifying the parts of plants), section preparation, and using botanical resources online. There are two phases, one quiz online via moodle, and the other test in class during the last lab week.

Feedback: For Moodle quiz, marks will be released on Moodle. Comments on the final lab test will be made on the exam papers and will be available after session. Comments and marks will be provided by academic staff.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c9b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f8b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"889b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f8be9b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Plant (weed) collection","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This is a field based assignment in which the students collect weeds from the outside world, turning in their field notes and making a preparation for the herbarium.  This teaches how herbarium collections work as well as observation skills in field work situation.

Feedback: Feedback will be provided by academic staff, in the form of comments on specimens and accompanying documentation

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c9b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f8b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"889b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b78be9b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Blog on plant families","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students research a plant family using online resources. They then prepare a blog post for the web designed for a general audience.  Students learn about writing for different audiences and develop some practice in discussing and presenting scientific information for different audiences.

Feedback: Marks and written comments will be provided by academic staff

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"489b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f8b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"889b2db3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ff8be9b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS2051.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Basic plant biology including cell structure, plant morphology and anatomy, water and sugar transport, seed structure and germination, plant growth and development, leaves and photosynthesis, roots, micro-organisms and nutrition, evolution of land plants and plant taxonomy. A strong emphasis is placed on Australian native flora. Practical work includes light microscopy;  plant anatomy and identification.Assumed knowledge: BIOS1101.
contentlets.title: Plant Biology

Australia has a high diversity of vertebrate species (e.g. platypus, tree frogs, parrots, snakes). This course examines the evolution, diversity and natural history of these animals with a special emphasis on how they cope with Australia's environment. It covers the evolutionary origins and relationships between the major Vertebrate groups and explores their diversity of form, function and behavior. There is a detailed investigation of birds and mammals, particularly their ecology, life history and emerging conservation issues. Practical work involves examining living and preserved specimens (including dissections) and several field trips around Sydney studying vertebrates in the wild.Please click here for further course details

This course examines the evolution, diversity and natural history of these animals with a special emphasis on how they cope with Australia's environment. It covers the evolutionary origins and relationships between the major Vertebrate groups and explores their diversity of form, function and behavior. There is a detailed investigation of birds and mammals, particularly their ecology, life history and emerging conservation issues. Ecology of marine and freshwater systems, emphasising benthic communities. Population and community dynamics of these systems. Evolution of life histories in the light of constraints of aquatic systems. Emphasis on experimental approaches to aquatic ecology. Special topics considered include chemical ecology, plant/herbivore ecology, and applied aspects of the topic such as mariculture. A section on the biology and taxonomy of marine algae (seaweeds) is included. Fieldwork is an important component of the course.Assumed Knowledge: MSCI1001 and BIOS1101.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"513ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Opinions in Ecology","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

In this exercise, students will select a topic that has been contentious and write an article that argues for one side of the debate (rather than reviews both sides of the debate). In doing so, you will need to acknowledge the criticisms of the concept you are supporting, and then argue against those criticisms. To do this successfully, you will need to read the literature critically, and select arguments and examples that support your side of the debate. The article should be written in the style of a popular science article, and may be illustrated with figures and tables. The topics will emphasise those issues that link marine and aquatic ecology to practical problems in conservation and management of coastal environments. It is in these areas that scientists need to be able to clearly argue their point of view.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within two weeks of assignment submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"993ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d53ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dd3ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"193ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Plant-herbivore report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to report the results of an experiment carried out during one of the practicals. The purpose of the practical is to teach some techniques of experimental design and execution in field experiments, and data analysis. The aim of this field experiment is to determine whether local herbivores affect the distribution and/or abundance of algae on our local shores. Students summarise the experiment and the findings in the form of a scientific report submitted to Marine Ecology Progress Series.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within one week of assignment submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"993ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d53ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d53ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dd3ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"253ee8b7dbea5010358b403c3a9619e6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Independent field project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Groups of students will sign up for research topics that can be addressed through field work in local marine and freshwater habitats. A list of topics will be made available through Moodle and will be discussed in the practicals. In this exercise, students will gain experience in carrying out independent research, including the formulation of their own hypotheses and sampling designs, and data collection, analysis, and interpretation, and communication of results. Students are required to summarise their findings in a report in the form of a scientific journal article.

Each group is also required to present a short talk on their field project. The aim is to educate the rest of the class on what was done and what was found. The presentation should include background information on your project, the specific hypotheses you aimed to test, the methods used to test the hypotheses, plus results and their interpretation.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within two weeks of assignment submission

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BIOS2123","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS2123 - Ecosystem Conservation and Management","description":"

This course has an intensive field trip component to the internationally important and spectacular Macquarie Marshes where you will sample wetland environments and learn about river management. The course takes students to the upper catchment of the Macquarie River and the major dam that regulates the river. After this, students will visit an irrigation property, before spending several days in the Macquarie Marshes, surveying and meeting key stakeholders who manage the Macquarie Marshes. The course focuses on advanced, practical management of environmental flows in rivers of the Murray-Darling Basin and conservation of endangered species and habitats endemic to Australia. Students will participate in the monitoring of wetland species, understanding conservation management and practical field skills required in monitoring environments. Practical training will include consideration of the implementation of conservation programs, including the social, institutional and logistical constraints placed on conservation management strategies. For more information, please visit here.


Note: This course is available to students in Advanced Science (3962), Science (3970) and their associated Dual Degrees, with a preference given to students in the Ecology Major. Unfilled places are available to students in Environmental Management (3965), Life Science (3966) with preference given to students in Biology or Ecology Majors with a credit average.


This course involves compulsory field-work and will this will involve expense to individual students. This course also includes a lecture component before the field trip.

In this assignment, you are required to choose one from the following two assignments (see section 13.3 below). You will present your assignment as a group to the rest of the participants at the end of the course. The presentation will take the form of a community consultation and information meeting, which you will run and present your plan for input and critique from the rest of the group (“the community”, which may include various stakeholders). Additional feedback will be given by academic staff during the presentation.

You will be assigned to groups at the beginning of the course, and as a group you should choose one from the following two assignments.

  1. Adaptive environmental management plan
  2. Species reintroduction plan.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7be6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"7be6917fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b7e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f3e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ffe6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5be6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The benefits of many skills and experiences you gain from practical experience will not be immediately obvious, but will become apparent through reflection of the processes and experiences in which you are engaging during your study. Acknowledgement and expression of how you feel about these experiences and where they fit in relation to other experiences or the ‘big picture’ facilitates your growth as a reflective practitioner. The aims of this course include to provide practical training and to facilitate experience of current ecosystem conservation and management strategies. This reflective exercise is designed to assess less tangible aspects of your learning and to highlight the importance of reflection to obtain a complete conservation experience.

Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"3fe6917fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"93e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Environmental management or reintroduction plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

In this assignment, you are required to choose one from the following two assignments which you present to the class as a group (see above section 13.2). You will incorporate the input of this consultation exercise into an individual written report, which will be submitted two weeks following the completion of the course. This report will constitute 35% of the course total, and feedback will be given no later than four weeks following submission.

You will be assigned to groups at the beginning of the course, and as a group you should choose one from the following two assignments.

  1. Adaptive environmental management plan
  2. Species reintroduction plan.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7be6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"7be6917fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b7e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f3e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ffe6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pre-course reading questions and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This assessment is made up of two parts, a short answer quiz and a short presentation. These are designed to ensure that students are familiar with the course materials and the environment that they will be working in before the field trip.

Short answer quiz:

After reading the pre-course reading, log in and answer 10 short-answer questions relating to it on Moodle. This assignment should be completed prior to the beginning of the course, and you will be informed of your mark before completion of the field course. This assessment is divided into two sections and is worth 10% of the total mark.

Short presentation:

Produce and present a 2-minute Powerpoint presentation describing an animal or plant that may be encountered on the course from the list below. Species will be assigned prior to the course (to allow you to collect some information on it), and individual students will present their talk following the evening meal from the third night.

Presentations must include the following headings:

  • Where do they live?
  • What is their role?         
  • What are their threats?
  • What needs to be done to conserve them?

This is an individual assignment. Presentations should also be uploaded to Moodle at the end of the course, and feedback will be provided on the course.

contentlets.description:
This course has an intensive field trip component to the internationally important and spectacular Macquarie Marshes where you will sample wetland environments and learn about river management. The course takes students to the upper catchment of the Macquarie River and the major dam that regulates the river. After this, students will visit an irrigation property, before spending several days in the Macquarie Marshes, surveying and meeting key stakeholders who manage the Macquarie Marshes. The course focuses on advanced, practical management of environmental flows in rivers of the Murray-Darling Basin and conservation of endangered species and habitats endemic to Australia. Students will participate in the monitoring of wetland species, understanding conservation management and practical field skills required in monitoring environments. Practical training will include consideration of the implementation of conservation programs, including the social, institutional and logistical constraints placed on conservation management strategies. For more information, please visit here.

Note: This course is available to students in Advanced Science (3962), Science (3970) and their associated Dual Degrees, with a preference given to students in the Ecology Major. Unfilled places are available to students in Environmental Management (3965), Life Science (3966) with preference given to students in Biology or Ecology Majors with a credit average.

This course involves compulsory field-work and will this will involve expense to individual students. This course also includes a lecture component before the field trip.
contentlets.title: Ecosystem Conservation and Management

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS2500 - Evolution and the Modern World","description":"

Evolution shaped the living world, from the flu virus to millions-strong colonies of leaf-cutter ants, and from simple sessile invertebrates to conscious and highly cultural humans. Darwin’s insight that evolution happens by natural selection remains, in the words of philosopher Daniel Dennett,  “the most important idea anybody ever had”. Unfortunately, only a small proportion of people ever gain more than a superficial understanding of natural selection and how evolution works. And that can be problematic given the important insights that evolution provides into the most difficult and persistent problems that plague 21st Century living, including antibiotic resistance, obesity, overpopulation, income inequality, gender inequity and the ideological warfare that surround sex and family life.


 This course introduces students from all areas of the university to the power of evolutionary thinking, and how to use it responsibly to understand modern life and the controversial issues that inhere to it. In addition to introducing the original - often counterintuitive - insights evolution provides, we explore the relationships between evolutionary, social, cultural and economic processes.


Learning involves on 2-hour lecture per week, plus a 1.5-2 hour workshop in which we will explore evolution using custom-designed video games and other interactive resources and data.


Assessment comprises three quizzes and an essay. There is no final exam.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2f7bf477dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Short essay (2,000 word maximum) exploring a contemporary news story from an evolutionary perspective. Students are asked to discuss how a concept from evolutionary biology provides insight into a current or recent news event.

Students are expected to explain to a recent high school graduate who has heard of evolution but not taken a course like this one how the concept/s from evolution help to make sense of what happened in the news story or how that story was interpreted by the media and the public.  

Students will be assessed on how well they understand and explain to the reader the evolutionary concepts and on how creative, interesting and insightful their analysis of the news story/event is. 

Students will submit essays via the course’s online portal. Essays will include the following.

i.                Headline for the news story or even

ii.              Source material to original story (e.g. URL to newspaper)

iii.             Name the key evolutionary concept or concepts involved. Can be a single concept, or multiple.

iv.             Title for essay. This should be informative and attention-grabbing.

v.              Essay should be written in an engaging and interesting way, using simple language and sentence structures, and well-structured paragraphs.  It should be of a level you might read in The Conversation, Slate, or Huffington Post. The body of the essay should not exceed 2000 words. Use numbered footnotes (eg. [1]) to refer to published papers, website articles, youtube videos etc. Normally these would be hyperlinks in your article.

vi.             Numbered references (see above). Please check your numbered call-outs match your references above. You need to cite at least four academic papers.

We have already drafted the guidelines for students for this exercise (see attached Draft Course Outline). We will provide time in three of the weekly workshops to support students through the process of choosing topics, planning and writing their essays.

Each student will submit a short, individually written review of one of the published research articles mentioned during the case study lecture or is clearly related to the topic.

Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"06f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"52f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8af2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3df2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Book review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Each student reads at least one recent popular science book that has some relevance to Animal Behaviour. It is designed to stimulate general reading and broad thinking about the relevance of animal behaviour to society, other aspects of biology and the human condition. Students are assessed on: the level of comprehension of the subject matter, demonstration of critical thinking, the clarity and quality of writing and how well the review is tailored to the questions.

Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"06f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"52f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"71f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative research project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Throughout the course students complete a major research project in groups of 3 or 4 students. Each research group will design the study, collect and analyse the data

Assessment is madeup of four parts:

  • Project proposal
  • Seminar presentation
  • Written paper
  • Self and peer assessment

Project proposal (0%)

Groups submit a proposal of their project to their academic advisor who will then provide critical feedback within one week of sumbission via return email. This part of the assessment is not marked, but provides important feedback on the research plan.

Seminar presentation (10%):

Each group presents the findings of their project to the class in practical time. Students are assessed as a group. Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within one week of the class

Written paper (20%):

Each group writes up the project up as a paper formatted for the academic journal Behavioral Ecology. Students are assessed as a group. Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within one week of submission

Self and peer assessment (5%):

Students submit a short exercise reflecting on the collaborative process within their research groups. Students are assessed individually for this portion of the assessment. Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within one week of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"06f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"52f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8af2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9ef2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c6f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b9f2ae63dbf99850eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam tests student understanding of the principles covered in the lecures and practicals and case studies

contentlets.description: Theory and practice in the biological study of animal behaviour: ethology and behavioural ecology. The observation and description of behaviour along with the development, function and evolution of behaviour in an ecological context are examined as important elements in the analysis of behaviour, particularly social behaviour. Topics include  sensory control systems, foraging behaviour, communication, home range, territorial behaviour, aggression and dominance, sexual behaviour, mate choice, mating systems, play and social organisation. Examples are drawn from the Australian fauna and both field and laboratory work are included.Assumed Knowledge: Animal systematics and morphology with BIOS2031 or BIOS2061 recommended

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BIOS3061","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS3061 - Plant Ecology","description":"

Topics include: plant-animal interactions, including herbivory, seed dispersal and pollination; biological invasions; disturbance, including life in fire-prone ecosystems and the effects of human influences on plant communities; plant regeneration, including reproduction and mating systems, and seed and seedling ecology; evolutionary radiations; plant ecological strategies. We incorporate evolutionary, population and community approaches to plant ecology, and include examples from Australia, and around the world. The course is not lecture based - rather, weekly meetings will be based on discussions facilitated and led by both lecturers and students.


A five day field excursion during mid-session break is compulsory and will involve expense to individual students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7daeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion groups","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The aim of the discussion group is to give students experience of synthesising information and ideas from the current ecological literature, presenting this information in an engaging manner, and facilitating a class discussion. In pairs, students prepare to lead a 45-minute class discussion, in which they explore an ecological controversy. Students are assessed on their depth of knowledge of research area, the quality of their presentation, and their capacity to facilitate class discussion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6daeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"71aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a9aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95ae716bdb359850eb6b147a3a9619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The end of session test evaluates student knowledge of the research material presented by their peers throughout the session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6daeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a9aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

The aim of this project is to give students experience of designing and carrying out their own research project, and to give students first-hand experience of plant ecological field work. During the field trip, students work in groups to conduct a research project testing ecological hypotheses. After the trip, students analyse and interpret their data, and prepare a research paper. Students are assessed on the quality of their individual research papers written in the format of manuscripts ready to submit to a top ecological journal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"35aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6daeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"71aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a9aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ddae716bdb359850eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes on readings","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Prior to the student-led discussion, the class is required to complete an assigned reading. Quizzes at the start of class measures understanding of this reading, and ensures that students are prepared to participate in the discussion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6daeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a9aeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"edaeb16bdb359850eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS3061.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description:
Topics include: plant-animal interactions, including herbivory, seed dispersal and pollination; biological invasions; disturbance, including life in fire-prone ecosystems and the effects of human influences on plant communities; plant regeneration, including reproduction and mating systems, and seed and seedling ecology; evolutionary radiations; plant ecological strategies. We incorporate evolutionary, population and community approaches to plant ecology, and include examples from Australia, and around the world. The course is not lecture based - rather, weekly meetings will be based on discussions facilitated and led by both lecturers and students.

A five day field excursion during mid-session break is compulsory and will involve expense to individual students.

Oceans occupy 75% of the planet's surface and have the capacity to moderate our climate and supply our food, water and oxygen. The East Australian Current also has a substantial (and unappreciated) effect on our lives. This course outlines the dominant players and processes in pelagic marine ecosystems, from fine-scale ocean physics, to nutrients, phytoplankton, zooplankton, fish and sharks. We will study estuarine ecosystems, including the effects of catchments and nutrients on hydrography and estuarine habitats. The systematics and ecology of fish in particular, but also sharks and rays will be a feature of the course. The 5 day field trip to the UNSW field station at Smiths Lake replaces many of the labs later in session, where students may learn practical skills (boats, nets) and theoretical skills (statistics and modelling using and EcoPath spreadsheet) . Other topics may include human impacts and possible solutions through engineering of pelagic ecosystems such as bottom-up ecosystem regulation through nutrient supply, or top-down regulation of ecosystems by sharks and other predators; removal of mid-level planktivores, and some bio-engineering solutions to degraded ecosystems: re-stocking of fish; ocean fertilization; and artificial reefs.


Assumed knowledge: BIOS2031 and BEES2041


Note: The course may include an intensive 5 day field trip to Smiths Lake held during the mid-session break.  This will involve personal expense to students for transportation, food and accommodation.

The lab exam is based on the exercises covered in the lab portion of the course. This assesses students’ ability to undertake practical exercises and use specialist equipment to collect and analyse data, as well as ability to identify and describe various marine specimens.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5317597fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9717197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d317197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d717197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b17197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Trip Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is made up of two components, a computer lab and a final written report. Feedback and marks from academic staff for both assessments will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission, general feedback will also be provided in class.

Computer intro (5%)

Students complete a number of computer exercises which teaches them how to manage and analyse data to produce a variety of tables and figures using specialised data analysis software

Final report (25%)

Students write up the findings of their field trip project. They are required to analyse and interpret their data, and present their findings in the form of a scientific paper from a marine ecology journal, such as Marine and Freshwater Research, or Marine Ecology Progress Series.

Knowledge & abilities assessed: Detailed knowledge of some classic fisheries and introduction/application of multivariate ecological statistics. Assessment Criteria: Correct answers to the questions that demonstrates you understand the processes.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BIOS3123 - Conservation in Practice","description":"


This course is an intensive field-based course which is run in conjunction with the management of endangered species. The course focuses on advanced, practical management of endangered species and habitats endemic to Australia and hence conservation practices. Students will participate in the monitoring of endangered species and gain skills in surveying methods including passive and active monitoring techniques. Practical training will include consideration of the implementation of conservation programs, including the financial and logistical constraints placed on conservation management strategies.


Assumed knowledge: BIOS1101 and BEES2041.


Note: This course is available to students in Advanced Science (3972), Science (3970) and their associated Dual Degrees, with a preference given to students in the Ecology Major. Unfilled places are available to students in Environmental Management (3965), Life Science (3966) with preference given to students in Biology or Ecology Majors with a credit average.


 


This course involves compulsory field-work and will this will involve expense to individual students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7471f0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961902","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You have been asked, as a conservation expert, to develop a recovery plan for your endangered species with an ultimate goal to expand the current information and improve on current conservation management strategies to safeguard their population. 

You have been allocated an initial budget of AU$300000 with AU$50000 each year thereafter for a total of 5             years (total AU$500000). Using the 4 C's of conservation (community, culture, commerce and conservation) and any data collected during the field trip, write a project proposal that further promotes and safeguards the recovery of the endangered population. You may use current recovery plans as a guide for structure.

 All strategies need to be properly researched and referenced and spending accounted for by including an itemised budget. This project proposal should reveal findings of the field trip and be supported with data collected during the field trip.


Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2471b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6071b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"7871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bc71b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The benefits of many skills and experiences you gain from practical experience will not be immediately obvious, but will become apparent through reflection of the processes and experiences in which you are engaging during your study. Acknowledgement and expression of how you feel about these experiences and where they fit in relation to other experiences or the ‘big picture’ facilitates your growth as a reflective practitioner.

The aims of this course include to provide practical training and to facilitate experience of current conservation management strategies. This reflective exercise is designed to assess less tangible aspects of your learning and to highlight the importance of reflection to obtain a complete conservation experience.

Please complete the following tasks:

a) in maximum of three paragraphs, Describe your impressions of the current state of conservation management in Australia and how you feel it should be approached.

b) briefly describe three important things you learnt about the constraints placed on conservation management strategies (and the organisations that implement them). Please rank these (with no.1 being the most important).Provide a brief justification why you ranked them in this order;

c) write one or two sentences each day describing the most outstanding thing you learnt that day.

d) write a maximum of two paragraphs describing your practical experience during this field trip (e.g. collection of field data, leadership) and what you learned about working in a group;

e) describe three important things you learnt during the field component of the course. Please rank these (with no. 1 being the most important to either your personal or professional development). Provide a brief justification on why you ranked them in this order.

 

This assessment should be short (no more than four pages using size12 font and standard margins). Adherence to this formatting will also be assessed.


Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

Review current conservation management practices in Australia and their effectiveness by comparing strategies of two endemic Australian animals. 1500 words, include 10-15 references.


Feedback will be given individually on marked essays no later than three weeks after submission.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6071b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"7871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bc71b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9871b0bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Local fauna and flora diversity","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Within conservation management it is important to consider the habitat as a whole, not only the subject animal. This practical exam focuses on other plants and birds from the local area and tests information given during habitat surveys.


Feedback will be given no later than three weeks after the exam.

Forty-four percent of Australia is desert and a further 37% is semi-arid grassland or shrub communities. These arid lands contribute much to our unique biodiversity. We examine the history of the formation of the Australian arid lands, their characteristics relative to other arid parts of the world, the evolutionary history of the flora and fauna, adaptations of plants and animals to arid environments, the major arid lands ecosystems and conservation of biodiversity. We apply biological knowledge to issues of land degradation, salinisation of soils, dryland farming, feral animal control and wildlife management for a sustainable future. A field trip to Western NSW is an essential part of the course and students will incur expenses.


Note: A compulsory field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred. Please see the course page on the UNSW BEES website for more details of this field trip (https://www.bees.unsw.edu.au/bios3161)


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f15ba9b6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961978","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Literature discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is made up of two parts: Leading paper discussion and Questions for paper discussion.

Leading paper discussion

During class time in early weeks, we will discuss as a class two scientific papers from the primary literature (15 mins each). The papers will be available on Moodle. For each paper, an assigned group of students will provide 2-3 slides oriented towards stimulating class discussion of the paper. Each student will be involved in leading discussion for one paper during the term. The grading for this is focused on 1) facilitation of class discussion; 2) clear understanding of the concepts and findings of the paper; 3) description of one data figure from the paper

Questions for paper discussion

The evening before class discussion, each student that is not involved in leading discussion must read and comment on one of the two chosen papers. After reading one of the two papers, you will go back into Moodle and provide short answers in response to the questions. Scores will be based on accuracy, as well as depth and breadth of understanding of the paper and its implications

Feedback for all assessments will be given in the form of marks and comments from academic staff

Feedback for all assessments will be given in the form of marks and comments from academic staff

This assessment is made up of two parts: The project presentation, and the project report.

Presentation

Each group will give a 10-minute powerpoint presentation on their research project. The presentation should include conceptual background/motivation, objectives of the research, graphical presentation of the results (including clear verbal explanation of the graph), and discussion of the results

Project report (independent)

A final report on the research project is due in the last week of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f15ba9b6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f55b6db6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f55ba9b6db8ea810eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fd5b6db6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fd5ba9b6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b55b6db6db8ea810eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This assessment contains four parts to assist students in developing their research projects and project reports:

Project proposal

Each group will prepare a scientific proposal for their research project to be completed at Fowlers Gap. This proposal will help students learn the conceptual background to their project, improve science communication, and assist in planning the project prior to the trip. The aim of this assignment is to focus your mind on the how and why of the research, and to help you visualize the process of the research.

Data sheet & materials list

As part of designing the overall group research project, each student group will design a datasheet to use in the field. These datasheets should anticipate the quantity, type and frequency of data collection.

Draft figures

Following the field trip, each student must independently generate a publication-style graphical presentation of their main data. Students may discuss the importance and implications of their data with their group mates, but the figures must be generated individually.

Comments on draft figures

Following the deadline for draft figure submission, each student must go onto Moodle, and select three research groups to cast a vote in. After selecting a research group, view all 3-4 figures and legends submitted individually by the group members. Vote for which figure in the group is the best, and provide constructive comments on why you think it is the best

Feedback will be given in the form of marks and comments from academic staff within 1 week of submission in preparation for the field trip

contentlets.description:
Forty-four percent of Australia is desert and a further 37% is semi-arid grassland or shrub communities. These arid lands contribute much to our unique biodiversity. We examine the history of the formation of the Australian arid lands, their characteristics relative to other arid parts of the world, the evolutionary history of the flora and fauna, adaptations of plants and animals to arid environments, the major arid lands ecosystems and conservation of biodiversity. We apply biological knowledge to issues of land degradation, salinisation of soils, dryland farming, feral animal control and wildlife management for a sustainable future. A field trip to Western NSW is an essential part of the course and students will incur expenses.

Note: A compulsory field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred. Please see the course page on the UNSW BEES website for more details of this field trip (https://www.bees.unsw.edu.au/bios3161)
contentlets.title: Life in Arid Lands

BIOS3171 Evolution is an advanced course covering the core concepts and research techniques of modern evolutionary biology. This course is also designed to help students develop their scientific communication skills. Students will participate in a 4-day field-trip to Smith's Lake field research station where they will learn hands-on by making observations and collecting biological data. Students will analyze their data, write a research paper, and create a short video to communicate their findings.


Assumed Knowledge: BIOS2011 Evolutionary and Physiological Ecology

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5962b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Video","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will prepare a short (5-min) video explaining the importance of the research question and findings from their Independent Research Project. Videos will be assessed by other students (peer assessment) and the course instructors. Feedback will be provided on the effectiveness of the videos as means of communicating scientific ideas in an accessible way.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1162b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1962b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d62f9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb35","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

In this assessment, students will examine evolutionary concepts, and review literature to identify a research topic that will become their independent research project. Students will first write an outline and a research proposal of the research question and methodology that they will use in their Independent Research Project. The outline and research proposal (submitted prior to the field-trip to Smith's Lake) will enable us to assess the ideas that students are working on for their major research project, and provide feed-back.

The research project will take place during the field trip at Smith's Lake Research Station.  Students will use their research proposals as a plan for conducting field research in evolutionary biology.  Students will collect and process data in the field, and perform initial analysis. Back at UNSW, students will analyse and interpret their data and write a report in the form of an empirical research paper. Individual written feed-back will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1162b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1162b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbde","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1562b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1962b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6162f9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb30","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Evolutionary Film Criticism","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment requires students to critique the evolutionary biology in a film of their choosing and submit a 1-page report. Students will watch a film that relates to evolutionary biology in some way (e.g. Jurassic Park, etc.) and critique the use of evolutionary ideas in the film. This assessment will be submitted prior to the field-trip. Individual written feedback will be provided.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1162b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1962b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dd62b9e21b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbdf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Quizzes will help the students gauge their own understanding and to review ideas from the previous week, will allow the instructors to assess student learning, and will encourage students to attend. At the start of each 2-hour tutorial-format meeting on campus, students will complete a short multiple-choice quiz (using Kahoot or a similar app). The quiz app will  automatically record student participation (providing a record of attendance) and student scores. Collectively, the quizzes will be worth 10% of the course mark. Students will find out the correct answers at the end of each quiz.

Students will analyze their data, write a research paper, and create a short video to communicate their findings.

contentlets.description: Systematics investigates historical aspects of evolution and establishes evidence-based classifications and genealogical relationships between organisms. Phylogenetic systematic also known as cladistics, provides a basis for hierarchical classification, which provides a framework for examining other evolutionary and biological events, such as historical biogeography, sexual coevolution, host-parasite coevolution are also used in applied research such as in conservation biology and biodiversity. This course is designed to introduce the principles and application of phylogenetic systematic using a variety of organisms. The laboratories will place emphasis on the use of computer software and examples from major clades of the Tree of life.
contentlets.title: Assembling the Tree of Life
