An advanced practical training in diversity, systematics, biology and identification of terrestrial animals and plants. The course is run principally as an intensive one (1) week course at Smiths Lake Field Station. Students will receive theoretical and practical training in current methods of trapping, collecting and identifying animals and plants, estimation of population size, biodiversity, the conduct of animal surveys, and data analyses. The course coverage will include both vertebrate and invertebrate animals and plants.


This course involves a compulsory field trip that will incur personal costs to students


Assumed knowledge: BEES2041 and familiarity with principles of systematics


Note: Enrolment available to students in Advanced Science, with unfilled places available to students in Environmental Science, Biological Science and Ecology Majors with a credit average.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"25e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb91","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Independent project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Working in groups of 3-5, students undertake a field sampling exercise to answer a basic question in biology/ecology and write a report on the results in the format of a scientific paper. Students will use skills obtained during the field trip in terms of understanding methods and problems in field sampling. Each student will then write up their own report on the data, written in the style of a paper submitted to a scientific journal.

Feedback: marks and comments from the course convener, academic staff and demonstrators will be provided via Moodle or in written comments on hard copy assignments

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69e2b5e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb5c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Each student is required to write a scientific report with Introduction, Methods, Results and Discussion using one of the data-sets collected during the field trip. This report is written in the style of a paper submitted to a scientific journal.

Feedback: marks and comments from the course convener, academic staff and demonstrators will be provided via Moodle or in written comments on hard copy assignments

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7de2b5e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb62","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Each research group will make a brief presentation of their group project that was undertaken during the term. The presentation should include the research question, approach and methods, results and discussion of the findings.

Feedback: marks will be released on Moodle, comments will be provided by the course convener, academic staff and demonstrators during the workshop

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b9e2b5e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbf4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Natural History project","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students undertake a natural history study of any organism or taxa of thier choosing in any medium they choose. The study can be (but is not limited to) a collection of photographs, a herbarium, a seed collection, a pinned insect collection, a shell collection, a series of line drawings, painting/s, a film, a detailed list of sightings, or musings.

This task assesses students' ability to make observations of organisms and record those observations

Feedback: marks and comments from the course convener, academic staff and demonstrators will be provided via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e275e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcb92","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f1e2b5e61b0ca810d5fb0fabdc4bcbf1","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS3601.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
An advanced practical training in diversity, systematics, biology and identification of terrestrial animals and plants. The course is run principally as an intensive one (1) week course at Smiths Lake Field Station. Students will receive theoretical and practical training in current methods of trapping, collecting and identifying animals and plants, estimation of population size, biodiversity, the conduct of animal surveys, and data analyses. The course coverage will include both vertebrate and invertebrate animals and plants.

This course involves a compulsory field trip that will incur personal costs to students

Assumed knowledge: BEES2041 and familiarity with principles of systematics

Note: Enrolment available to students in Advanced Science, with unfilled places available to students in Environmental Science, Biological Science and Ecology Majors with a credit average.

Assessment Criteria: Correct answers to the questions that demonstrates you understand the processes

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9617197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8617197fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field trip report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is made up of two components, a computer lab and a written report. Feedback and marks from academic staff for both components will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission, general feedback will also be provided in class

Computer intro (5%)

Students complete a number of computer exercises which teaches them how to manage and analyse data to produce a variety of tables and figures using specialised data analysis software

Final report (25%)

Students write up the findings of their field trip project. They are required to analyse and interpret their data, and present their findings in the form of a scientific paper from a marine ecology journal, such as Marine and Freshwater Research, or Marine Ecology Progress Series.

contentlets.description:
Oceans occupy 75% of the planet's surface and have the capacity to moderate our climate and supply our food, water and oxygen. The East Australian Current also has a substantial (and unappreciated) effect on our lives. EECO outlines the dominant players and processes in pelagic marine ecosystems, from fine-scale ocean physics, to nutrients, phytoplankton, zooplankton, fish and sharks. We will study estuarine ecosystems, including the effects of catchments and nutrients on hydrography and estuarine habitats. The systematics and ecology of fish in particular, but also sharks and rays will be a feature of the course. The 4 day field trip to Smiths Lake replaces many of the labs later in session. Other topics may include human impacts and possible solutions through engineering of pelagic ecosystems such as bottom-up ecosystem regulation through nutrient supply, or top-down regulation of ecosystems by sharks and other predators; removal of mid-level planktivores, re-stocking of fish; ocean fertilization; carbon sequestration; and artificial reefs.

Assumed knowledge: BIOS2031 and BEES2041

Note: Available to students in Advanced Science- Life Sciences and, subject to the availability of places, to students in BEnvironSci (Biology and Marine) and in 3970 (Biological Science, Ecology, and Biological Oceanography Majors with a credit average or better in BIOS courses). A compulsory field trip will be held during the mid-session break, and will involve personal expense to individual students.
contentlets.title: Ocean to Estuarine Ecosystems (Advanced)

Biodiversity and Conservation: Natural Resources (Advanced)","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/BIOS3671","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BIOS3671","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BIOS6671 - Biodiversity and Conservation of Natural Resources","description":"

Note: This course was previously offered as  BIOS3071  but changed to  BIOS6671  as of 2011.


The course covers applications of community ecology, population biology and genetics to the management of natural resources, environmental problems and conservation of biodiversity. Principles are conveyed using examples from terrestrial and marine flora and fauna, with a focus on the nature and importance of global diversity, and the design and management of programs for the conservation of species and ecosystems.


Note 1: Field excursions are compulsory and will involve additional expense to individual students

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2d99697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Threatened Species Management Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Research (gather and synthesising) biological, social and legal information. Conduct analyses to produce predictions to inform the decision-making process. Writing skills. Communicate scientific information in a clear, well researched report format- ability to follow instructions and use the tools available to produce a high quality adaptive management report. As third year students, all reports are expected to be supported by citations of relevant peer-reviewed scientific literature, and critical evaluation of other non-reviewed information such as websites.

Feedback: Individual feedback given during and after assessment via Turnitin.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1599697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ad99697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0599697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessing the student’s understanding of key concepts presented in the lectures.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1599697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5199697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ad99697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e999697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5d99697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Debate and Press Release","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Debate: Work as part of a team to conduct background research on a current controversial news topic on conservation. Identify, assess and discuss, the for and against augments of the topic. The group must evenly integrate and evaluate both sides of the story. Understand and communicate the scope of the conservation issue. Present arguments (for or against) in the style of an adjournment debate. Student’s ability to communicate argument(s) clearly and concisely in a 2-3-minute time frame. Communicate Participation in Q and A session after the debate. Media release: Written summary of the debate with an argument for or against.

Feedback: Group feedback given in lab time, and individual feedback given via Moodle Gradebook.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1599697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5199697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ad99697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e999697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8199697fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment Field or Non","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Option 1: (for those attending a field trip) Activity Monitoring: In field activity participation (field monitoring activities). These activities will take place during the field trip in week 6. 

Option 2: (for those not attending a field trip) Monitoring Report: Produce a report on the legal issues surrounding threatened species monitoring. 1500 words

Feedback: Individual feedback given during and after assessment via Turnitin.

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BIOS6692","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BIOS6692 - Advanced Underwater Field Ecology","description":"

This course is a field-based course offering students advanced practical training in conducting marine ecological field studies underwater. This course will facilitate learning of safe research practices in marine ecology by exposing students to a wide variety of equipment, methodologies and training. A major focus of this course will be for students to obtain the unrestricted scientific diver qualifications necessary to perform marine research under current WHS regulations. Students will gain practical experience and insight into the constraints of conducting field based research in the marine environment. This course will enable students to be registered for SCUBA diving based research at UNSW and will provide extensive boating experience.


 


Assumed knowledge: Evolutionary and Functional Biology and BEES2041 Data Analysis for Life and Earth Sciences.


 


Pre-requisites for this course are: Open Water Diving certification and an Occupational Dive Medical certificate.


 


Note: This course is available to students in the Bachelor of Advanced Science and Bachelor of Science and their associated Dual Degrees, with a preference given to students in the Marine majors. Unfilled places are available to students in the Bachelor of Environmental Management and Bachelor of Life Science, with preference given to students in Biology or Ecology majors with a credit average. This course will also be available to students in the study abroad program that are undertaking similar programs internationally.


 


This course involves compulsory field-work and certifications, which will involve additional expense to individual students.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"65457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Taxonomy quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to identify marine organisms to a fine scale of classification with a high degree of accuracy. This assessment tests students' knowledge of marine taxonomy and their understanding of the importance of standardised sampling for global data sharing. 

Feedback: marks will be instantly available, and general feedback will be discussed in class

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"65457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"15457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Scientific diver quiz and exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

These examinations test students' SCUBA diving theory knowledge, and tests their ability to demonstrate confident and safe diving skills. This includes but is not limited to, First aid skills, Safety and the use of oxygen therapy; Adherence to WHS policy; Adherence to industry codes of practice; Risk assessments; Risk control methods; Core diving skills; Dive table calculations; Deep diving & planning procedures; Search and recovery skills; Rigging skills; Boat diving and ocean awareness skills; Rescue techniques and skills; The use of surface supply; Methods of communication; and Scientific research skills and basic research techniques.

Feedback: Marks will be posted on Moodle, verbal comments and feedback will be provided in class during the practical by the demonstrators and academic staff

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"29457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Diving H&S Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

This quiz tests students' knowledge and compliance with health and safety guidelines at UNSW

Feedback: Marks will be available immediately after the quiz, and the answers will be discussed in class by academic staff and demonstrators

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"29457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"81457437dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Independent Field Project - report and oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Students will complete an independent field project using the skills gained throughout the course. This will involve planning the research to answer ecological questions, collecting data using appropriate methodology, analysing the data collected, interpreting the results of analysis in a ecologically meaningful way, and communicating these results to a scientific audience using peer reviewed literature.

Students will also present the results from their independent field projects in a 10 minute 'scientific conference style' presentation. This includes the preparation of visual aids such as, but not limited to power point slides.

This assessment tests ability to design a sampling program, to test specific hypothesis or perform a review to suitably high standard, ability to conduct ecological research in the field, ability to prepare scientific report, the ability to communicate the aims, methods and result of a marine science study, in plain English, to a wide audience background, and the ability to critically assess peers

Feedback: Marks and comments for the presentations will be provided by peers and demonstrators one week after the assessment. For the scientific reports, marks and comments will be provided via Moodle through Turnitin from demonstrators.

This course is an intensive field-based course located in Botswana's Okavango Delta, one of the world's hotspots of biodiversity and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Students will also take the course with students and staff from Arizona State University and Kings College London as part of the PLuS Alliance with UNSW. We will also have lectures from researchers from the Okavango River Institute, part of the University of Botswana. The Okavango Delta has extensive wetland systems with diverse waterbird populations, vegetation communities, the largest population of elephants in Africa and large predators, including lions and leopards. This diverse ecosystem lies at the end of one of the world's last few large free-flowing rivers. This course will involve non-government and government managers involved in practical concepts of river basin ecosystem conservation, management and governance. Students will acquire an advanced understanding of the politics, governance and management of river basin ecosystem science by unpacking the geopolitical constraints and considerations shaping the Delta's management. It receives most of its water from Angola with the Okavango River, which then flows through Namibia to Botswana. Participants will gain skills in field methods, ecosystem scale landscape analyses and their application to human/wildlife interactions. They will contribute to long-term collection of data for the management of the river basin. The overall aim of the course is to tackle a global challenge in a developing country of the world, focusing on sustainability of biological and abiotic processes within the context of human drivers of development. It uses the Okavango River Delta as a case study but compares this to Australian systems, particularly the Lake Eyre Basin. For more information, visit here.


This course involves compulsory field-work in Botswana. The field course costs and travel to and from Botswana is at the expense of individual students.This course will also have scheduled classes during the term. There is limited capacity in this course: preference will be given to high performing students in relevant Programs or Majors.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"43e6517fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"River basin environmental monitoring plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Collecting, recording, preserving and analyzing data about environmental and social conditions in a river basin is essential to support good management of the basin's resources. You have been asked to develop a 10-year environmental monitoring plan for the Cubango-Okavango river basin. You need to ensure participation and consistency from the three riparian countries dependent on the basin’s resources. All methodology needs to be properly researched and referenced. The plan should incorporate monitoring of flow and ecosystem indicator species. It should adopt a Strategic Adaptive Management Plan framework which begins with a vision and becomes increasingly complex and action oriented through a hierarchy of objectives. You should include the relevant datasheets and make reference to the relevant partners and stakeholders that will be engaged in the work. 

Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

This is a group-based practical exercise, involving surveying particular ecosystem indicator species. You will be introduced to field survey techniques and equipment in tutorial format, and will conduct surveys in small groups. You will be assessed on your practical skills in conducting the survey, and your ability to correctly identify and record particular indicator species.

contentlets.keywords: biological science,river basin ecosystem management.,environmental flow.
contentlets.description:
This course is an intensive field-based course located in Botswana's Okavango Delta, one of the world's hotspots of biodiversity and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Students will also take the course with students and staff from Arizona State University and Kings College London as part of the PLuS Alliance with UNSW. We will also have lectures from researchers from the Okavango River Institute, part of the University of Botswana. The Okavango Delta has extensive wetland systems with diverse waterbird populations, vegetation communities, the largest population of elephants in Africa and large predators, including lions and leopards. This diverse ecosystem lies at the end of one of the world's last few large free-flowing rivers. This course will involve non-government and government managers involved in practical concepts of river basin ecosystem conservation, management and governance. Students will acquire an advanced understanding of the politics, governance and management of river basin ecosystem science by unpacking the geopolitical constraints and considerations shaping the Delta's management. It receives most of its water from Angola with the Okavango River, which then flows through Namibia to Botswana. Participants will gain skills in field methods, ecosystem scale landscape analyses and their application to human/wildlife interactions. They will contribute to long-term collection of data for the management of the river basin. The overall aim of the course is to tackle a global challenge in a developing country of the world, focusing on sustainability of biological and abiotic processes within the context of human drivers of development. It uses the Okavango River Delta as a case study but compares this to Australian systems, particularly the Lake Eyre Basin. For more information, visit here.

This course involves compulsory field-work in Botswana. The field course costs and travel to and from Botswana is at the expense of individual students.This course will also have scheduled classes during the term. There is limited capacity in this course: preference will be given to high performing students in relevant Programs or Majors.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BIOS9123 - Conservation in Practice","description":"

BIOS9123 is an intensive field-based course which is run in conjunction with the management of endangered species. The course focuses on advanced, practical management of endangered species and habitats endemic to Australia and hence conservation practices. Students will participate in the monitoring of endangered species and gain skills in surveying methods including passive and active monitoring techniques. Practical training will include consideration of the implementation of conservation programs, including the financial and logistical constraints placed on conservation management strategies.


Note: This course is available to postgraduate students following relevant Graduate Diploma, Graduate Certificate and Masters by coursework programs, including Graduate Diploma of Environmental Management (5499), Graduate Certificate of Environmental Management (7339), Master of Environmental Management (8623) and Master of Marine Science and Management (8271).   


This course involves compulsory field-work and this will involve expense to individual students.


Assumed knowledge: Basic biology and statistics

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Local fauna and flora diversity","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Within conservation management it is important to consider the habitat as a whole, not only the subject animal. This practical exam focuses on other plants and birds from the local area and tests information given during habitat surveys.


Feedback will be given no later than three weeks after the exam.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"9e52783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3552783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

Concise, clear and effective communication is integral to the implementation of successful conservation management strategies. This assessment is designed to develop your communication and interpretation skills as a conservation manager through the presentation of your key conservation strategies that you have proposed in your project proposal to an 'expert' panel.


Feedback will be collated and given individually no later than three weeks after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"1652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"5252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ce52783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d52783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You have been asked, as a conservation expert, to develop a recovery plan for your endangered species with an ultimate goal to expand the current information and improve on current conservation management strategies to safeguard their population. 

You have been allocated an initial budget of AU$300000 with AU$50000 each year thereafter for a total of 5             years (total AU$500000). Using the 4 C's of conservation (community, culture, commerce and conservation) and any data collected during the field trip, write a project proposal that further promotes and safeguards the recovery of the endangered population. You may use current recovery plans as a guide for structure.

 All strategies need to be properly researched and referenced and spending accounted for by including an itemised budget. This project proposal should reveal findings of the field trip and be supported with data collected during the field trip.


Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"1652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ce52783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a152783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The benefits of many skills and experiences you gain from practical experience will not be immediately obvious, but will become apparent through reflection of the processes and experiences in which you are engaging during your study. Acknowledgement and expression of how you feel about these experiences and where they fit in relation to other experiences or the ‘big picture’ facilitates your growth as a reflective practitioner.

The aims of this course include to provide practical training and to facilitate experience of current conservation management strategies. This reflective exercise is designed to assess less tangible aspects of your learning and to highlight the importance of reflection to obtain a complete conservation experience.

Please complete the following tasks:

a) in maximum of three paragraphs, Describe your impressions of the current state of conservation management in Australia and how you feel it should be approached.

b) briefly describe three important things you learnt about the constraints placed on conservation management strategies (and the organisations that implement them). Please rank these (with no.1 being the most important).Provide a brief justification why you ranked them in this order;

c) write one or two sentences each day describing the most outstanding thing you learnt that day.

d) write a maximum of two paragraphs describing your practical experience during this field trip (e.g. collection of field data, leadership) and what you learned about working in a group;

e) describe three important things you learnt during the field component of the course. Please rank these (with no. 1 being the most important to either your personal or professional development). Provide a brief justification on why you ranked them in this order.

 

This assessment should be short (no more than four pages using size12 font and standard margins). Adherence to this formatting will also be assessed.


Feedback will be given individually on each report, given no later than four weeks after submission.

Review current conservation management practices in Australia and their effectiveness by comparing strategies of two endemic Australian animals. 1500 words, include 10-15 references.


Feedback will be given individually on marked essays no later than three weeks after submission.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"1652783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8252783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ce52783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f952783fdb751c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS9123.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
BIOS9123 is an intensive field-based course which is run in conjunction with the management of endangered species. The course focuses on advanced, practical management of endangered species and habitats endemic to Australia and hence conservation practices. Students will participate in the monitoring of endangered species and gain skills in surveying methods including passive and active monitoring techniques. Practical training will include consideration of the implementation of conservation programs, including the financial and logistical constraints placed on conservation management strategies.

Note: This course is available to postgraduate students following relevant Graduate Diploma, Graduate Certificate and Masters by coursework programs, including Graduate Diploma of Environmental Management (5499), Graduate Certificate of Environmental Management (7339), Master of Environmental Management (8623) and Master of Marine Science and Management (8271).   

This course involves compulsory field-work and this will involve expense to individual students.

Assumed knowledge: Basic biology and statistics
contentlets.title: Conservation in Practice

Students are required to submit a summary of their proposed project in the form of an abstract early in the term. This task ensures that students have undertaken appropriate readings and planning for their project to ensure successful completion of the project by the end of the term. They also receive early feedback on their ideas and project plan from their academic supervisor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"094b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"454b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"814b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"854b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"384b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students present the findings of their independent project in a short conference-style seminar. The aim is to educate a scientific audience on their research project and their major findings. The presentation should include background information on the project, the specific hypotheses the student aimed to test, the methods used to test the hypotheses, plus results and their interpretation. Marks and comments from academic staff within the school will be provided to the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"094b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"454b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"814b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"854b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"704b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"70","description":"

Throughout the term, students will work in conjunction with their academic supervisor to complete an independent research project. This is a substantive task and takes up a majority of the work for this course. The research project can either take the form of an empirical research or quantitative project, or a literature review. This will depend on the research interests of the student. In this exercise, students will gain experience in carrying out independent research, including the formulation of their own hypotheses and sampling designs, data collection, analysis, and interpretation, and communication of results. At the end of the term, students are required to summarise their findings in a report in the form of a scientific journal article. Marks and comments from academic staff within the school will be provided to the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"094b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"454b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"814b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"854b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b84b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Scientific seminars report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Throughout their internship, students are required to regularly attend research seminars hosted by the school of BEES. The purpose of attending these seminars is to expose students to a range of scientific ideas, and so that students become familiar with the range of different methods and approaches to biological study. Attendance will also show students how scientists communicate their research to other scientists, which is an important part of biological research.

To demonstrate their comprehension of the research presented, students are required to write a short summary of three of the seminars. This assesses student understanding of the topic, their ability to synthesise and summarise information, and their understanding of the broader implications of the research presented. Feedback (comments and marks) is provided to students within 2 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"854b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fc4b626bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96197f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BIOS9231.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course provides training in the basic skills required for conservation research, through internship within a research group in the School of Biological Earth and Environmental Sciences. The internship will provide intensive, hands on training in aspects of scientific research relevant to conservation, combining some or all of the following elements:a)experimental designb)literature searchesc)field and lab techniquesd)data analysis and modelinge)scientific writingAssessment is based on attendance in the lab and field, development of analytical and presentation skills, and a substantial literature review. The review topic will be selected by the student in consultation with the Course Authority, and will cover a conservation topic relevant to the research group, or a species or ecosystem the research group is studying.A list of potential projects and supervisors can be obtained through the Course Authority after enrolments for S2 open. Each student must develop their own program in consultation and collaboration with the Academic supervisor, ideally involving exposure to a broad cross-section of the elements involved in scientific research. This could include interaction with municipal and state government, community groups and appropriate industry bodies for possible projects. The program includes compulsory attendance at weekly school seminars, and a limited number of classes aimed at developing research skills.
contentlets.title: Research Internship in Marine Terrestrial Conservation
